questiontext.text:
Evaluate the sum of the infinite series :
$$\small \sum _{n=0}^{\infty }\:[2(\frac{1}{4})^n-5(\frac{1}{6})^n]$$

[Calculate upto 2 significant figures]

Answer :
{1:NUMERICAL:=-3.3333:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

generalfeedback.text:
This contains two geometric series with first term a = 1 and common ratios $$\small \frac{1}{4}$$ and $$\small \frac{1}{6}$$ respectively.
Number of terms n = $$\small \infty$$
Sum = $$\small \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r}$$
Sum =  -3.3333

$$\small \sum _{n=0}^{\infty }\:[4(\frac{1}{4})^n+3(\frac{1}{8})^n]$$

[Calculate upto 2 significant figures]

Answer :
{1:NUMERICAL:=8.7619:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

generalfeedback.text:
This contains two geometric series with first term a = 1 and common ratios $$\small \frac{1}{4}$$ and $$\small \frac{1}{8}$$ respectively.
Number of terms n = $$ \small \infty$$
Sum = $$\small \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r}$$
Sum =  8.7619
